segments.text: Do you agree with the idea that the grant giving agency should be primarily located in Washington?
I hadn't thought about their location, but I think
I think if I had to make a judgment, I would say yes.
They should all be in Washington.
Well, again, the general feelings of many oceanographers is that there ought to be multiple agency granting in Washington, D.C. itself, because that's close to the heartbeat of Congress.
Would you accept that idea, that it's necessary to be close to the seat of power, if I may use that word?
Well, I suppose it helps you when it comes time to testify before Congress.
But I don't think it's the key issue.
To me, the key issue is that if all of the granting agencies are in Washington,
they can work better together to support each other and their cause on the Hill and the research scientists.

I think if you're way out in another part of the country, even though the flying time is short, you begin to lose awareness of what other agencies are doing and where the gaps are from a management point of view and where the opportunities are.
How much interchange would you have with ONR, for example, on a grant?
Well, we have a lot of interchange with them.
They invite us to all of their site visits, and where possible, all of our program managers participate.
We can't do it all because it's a very heavy travel schedule.
They participate in our proposal review panel meetings.
In general, we have a great deal of interaction with them.
Our closest contact in the past has been with them.
Do you agree with the idea that the grant giving agency should be primarily located in Washington?
I hadn't thought about their location, but I think
I think if I had to make a judgment, I would say yes.
They should all be in Washington.
Well, again, the general feelings of many oceanographers is that there ought to be multiple agency granting in Washington, D.C. itself, because that's close to the heartbeat of Congress.
Would you accept that idea, that it's necessary to be close to the seat of power, if I may use that word?
Well, I suppose it helps you when it comes time to testify before Congress.
But I don't think it's the key issue.
To me, the key issue is that if all of the granting agencies are in Washington, they can work better together to support each other and their cause on the Hill and the research scientists.

way out in another part of the country, even though the flying time is short, you begin to lose awareness of what other agencies are doing and where the gaps are from a management point of view and where the opportunities are.
How much interchange would you have with ONR, for example, on a grant?
We have a lot of interchange with them.
They invite us to all of their site visits.
And where possible, all of our program managers participate.
You can't do it all because it's a very heavy travel schedule.
They participate in our proposal review panel meetings.
In general, we have a great deal of interaction with them.
Our closest contact in the past has been with ONR.
partly because some of us came from ONR and we knew the people who were there, partly because they're right here in town, and partly because we support the same people.
We had some coordinating committee set up between us and ONR when they were at NRL.
Now that they're in Mississippi, we don't have any arrangements.
And we really need to set up.
some arrangements in a formal way just to make sure that we do something periodically.
If you don't have what says I've got to get together with ONR on a certain day and talk about things, you never get together with them unless they're passing through town.
I haven't been to Mississippi since 1970 or something like this.
And so I think communication between the funding agencies is very important.
I think we could do a better job if we knew what EPA was doing.
But we don't know what EPA is doing.
And it's very hard to find out.
It's so hard to find out that we don't even bother, which is kind of a sad commentary.
My impression is that more and more agencies are going to be funding projects dealing in and around with oceanography and the atmosphere.
rather than fewer.
Do you think there's any likelihood of any simple direction?
But it does people like Gordon Lill who argue for simple direction maintain that that would bring in more cooperation from one of these agencies.
I'm really not sure about that.
I've never seen central coordination, at least thus far, work in the federal government.
I suppose if there were an oceanographic czar, it would work.
But I'm not sure that's healthy for oceanography.
So I guess I'm not overly enthusiastic about central coordination.
This was done, I believe, when the Weather Bureau was established.
And for a while, I guess it was pretty nice.
All the weather bureau activities were located in one place, and they served all the agencies and met their needs.
But it didn't take long before some of the agencies had needs that could not be met by this group, like maybe the Department of Agriculture or FAA.
And so pretty soon, these other agencies were establishing their own meteorological
programs to meet their own needs.
And I think it's a natural state of government.
If an agency needs a basic research component, it should be allowed to have it.
If it needs a mission-oriented research component, it should be allowed to have it.
It should have to justify it, of course, but at least the responsibility for doing the work that that agency wants doing lies on its own shoulders instead of
on some other agency over here which has its own fish to fry.
And I take it you'd be opposed to the so-called czarist approach to oceanography?
I would be, yeah.
It's almost as if oceanography is on the verge of, let me say, another breakthrough in funding.
Some people argue that the IGY created a massive funding program for oceanography, and they're very optimistic demands of cleaning up the environment will create one for them.
Is this the way you perceive it, having worked and going to work?
I'm not sure that it's about to have a breakthrough in funding.

I think the problem in the past has been that in spite of the fact that the advocacy group for oceanography has not been very large, it has been vocal enough so that oceanography has fared reasonably well in the scientific field.
programs of the agencies.
I think now that the number of advocates is increasing at a great rate.
We're going to exploit the outer continental shells.
We're going to face the problem more and more of waste disposal.
We're going to have power plant siting.
The whole thing has made
a large number of people aware of the oceans and the fact that the oceans are important, and this never existed before.
So, you know, if the number of advocates has any impact on the funding, then I'd say we should have a funding breakthrough within the next five years or so.
But I'm not sure whether or not.
Any particular politicians you'd like to cite for aiding funding in oceanography?
Oh, yeah, sure.
I think Miller of California was a strong supporter.
I think Jackson of Washington, before he got into other things, was a strong supporter.
And his staff was.
Certainly Hollings has been.
And Pell, who
has had a strong impact on the establishment of the Sea Grant program.
And those are the ones that stand out in my mind.
I'm not a great politician, so I don't keep track of it too well.
When Sea Grant was established, what sort of reaction did you go through?
What kind of contact did you have with the establishment of Sea Grant?
I didn't have any contact with the establishment of Sea Grant.
I didn't really have a reaction.
I have a very slow reaction time to some of these things.
And it took me several years to get concerned about whether it grew.
or collapsed or did anything else because we were busy with our own program.

I have been convinced for the past four or five years, though, that it's a very important program and that it needs to expand and needs to take an appropriate place in the same way the Department of Agriculture did.
in those states that border the oceans and need to deal effectively with the oceans.
So I'm a very strong supporter of the Sea Grant program.

Well, both the previous questions I was trying to pose in terms of multiplicity of funding is that can you think of anything like another program like Sea Grant or something that would interest other congressmen towards oceanography that should be done?
Or do we have enough agencies?
Enough interest in Congress.
Oh, I don't think you can have too many interests at Congress.
There are some problems.
Some of the problems that I mentioned earlier could stand a strong leadership from
but not necessarily in a new agency, but in one of the existing agencies.
I think the marine pollution program is one that is just drifting.
NOAA has a responsibility for monitoring.
I think for the first time last year, it got some money to set up a monitoring scheme.
There is no, EPA has so many problems on the continent and in freshwater that it's concerned about
saltwater is negligible.
There just isn't anybody who has both the concern and the resources to do anything about marine pollution monitoring.
And I think, you know, I think NOAA could do it if Congress had given the mandate and the money in a stronger term.
The exploitation following the Iron Continental Shelf is so difficult that I don't have any recommended procedure for tackling it.
BLM has an absolutely impossible chore, and they're getting pinged on from anybody that you want to mention.
There's nobody that they've been able to make happy.
And I'm not sure they can make anybody happy.
So they're under fire, and they've got a tremendous big program in terms of dollars.
I think someone should turn the management of that thing upside down.
But I don't think it's in the technical direction of it.
I think it's in the way that the Department of Interior chooses to negotiate these contracts for baseline studies and this sort of thing.
Maybe it's the only way they know, but I think it could stand a good shakeup.
I think that's a big part of the problem.
I don't know about the deep sea exploitation.
I think it's still a decade or two away.
And in large measure, the problems are more political
than technical, scientific.
Let me pose the question another way.
Other people maintain just as vigorously that with rapidly rising inflation, that funding for hard science projects will become less in the future rather than more.
Do you have, I know that that's obviously something we all oppose, but do you hear any rumors of this sort?
Any feelings that this may have?
No, it's certainly something to be concerned about.
And it's certainly going to cut back on the expansion of hard sciences.
Well, I don't get any signals that we're in for a disastrous cutback.
in the hard science support, at least in NSF and as far as I know, anywhere else.
